awd_titl_txt: FMitF: Collaborative Research: Track I: Predictive Online Safety Analysis from Multi-hop State Estimates for High-autonomy on Highways
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to bring safety assurance to autonomous and semi-autonomous vehicles. The approach is to lengthen the time that a car can predict its driving path, and share this path with surrounding vehicles. With these expanded predictions, it is possible to estimate the current and future behaviors of vehicles, according to their design models. Currently, online formal safety analysis can promise guarantees and oversight, but overly conservative approaches can lead to bad driving. This is in contrast to the use of test-driving data and machine learning to build driving models, which are difficult to analyze. The project aims to discover the right balance by computationally (1) estimating the current state of the autonomous vehicle and its multi-hop environment from sensor data, (2) predicting vehicle trajectories 4-6 seconds into future, and (3) checking the models and predictions---all in milliseconds. A new scientific workshop will be created to explore similar issues in autonomy, in addition to a new undergraduate course on autonomy.

The project aims to deliver (1) new sensor-fusion algorithms over Vehicle-to-Infrastructure/Vehicle (V2X) systems, (2) a first-of-its-kind open, machine-interpretable library of agent models for driving predictions, (3) algorithms for model identification, and (4) algorithms for checking safety online. These modules will be integrated in an end-to-end system --- OmniVisor --- and evaluated in realistic accident-prone scenarios with real vehicles in University of Michigan's Mcity facility. The research will build connections across the disciplines of formal methods, hybrid dynamical systems, estimation and detection theory, and mobile networking. If successful OmniVisor will provide a scientific basis for obtaining safety assurances for vehicles in mixed-autonomy scenarios and experimentally demonstrate the approach on the road with real vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Assuring the safety of autonomous and semi-autonomous vehicles on the highways require rigorous validation and verification beyond testing. Formal validation and verification artifacts can be used at run-time to equip the autonomy software with an ability to assess the safety of its current state. The main goal of this project was to develop online formal analysis and distributed state estimation algorithms for autonomous and connected vehicles. 

The approach that was developed had four components: i) estimation and sensor fusion algorithms that use information from multiple sources to construct the current state of the vehicle, ii) a composable and verifiable agent modeling framework suitable for a large number of high-way interactions, iii) algorithms for model identification and identifiability analysis, iv) fast reachability based algorithms for checking safety online. Some of the developed theory and algorithms are broadly applicable but we demonstrated their use in automative safety systems. The major problems that were investigated by the University of Michigan team are as follows:

1. A new hybrid automaton model, namely inter triggering hybrid automaton, that can be used for modeling a rich set of interactions between multiple vehicle in a compositional way, together with new efficient compositional safety verification rules applicable to this modeling framework.

2. Algorithms and theory for scalable backward reachable set computation using zonotopes. These algorithms can be used for safe control design, run-time safety checks and monitoring, or model validation. 

3. Algorithms for analyzing model identifiability. 

4. An open source software platform for continuous integration and testing for autonomous racing software.

The research conducted in this project resulted in rigorous methodologies for the design and run-time assurance of safe autonomous systems. These methodologies have the potential to significantly impact the safe deployment of autonomous vehicles and other autonomous systems of societal importance. Results were published in archival journals and conference proceedings, and disseminated via invited talks.

This project contributed to the training of several undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Michigan in the important area of safe and modular design and run-time safety assurance of autonomous vehicles.
